importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The publication date reflects the current state of anti-science legislation in U.S. statehouses, indicating a timely and ongoing political effort targeting public health policies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on legislative developments in 2025, highlighting a wave of anti-science bills introduced across U.S. states during this year.

keyTakeAways: Hundreds of anti-science bills targeting public health protections — including vaccines, fluoride in water, and milk safety — have been introduced in 50 U.S. states.
Over 350 anti-vaccine bills were the most common type, with at least 26 enacted or adopted in 11 states as of 2025.
More than 70 bills aim to roll back or eliminate fluoride in public water systems or make raw milk consumption easier, often by removing consumer safety regulations.

The bills are largely supported by four national groups linked to Robert F. Kennedy Jr.: MAHA Action, Stand for Health Freedom, National Vaccine Information Center (NVIC), and the Weston A. Price Foundation.
These groups engage in coordinated political strategies, including phone campaigns, social media outreach, Zoom calls, and testifying in state legislatures.
Advocates argue their positions are based on 'credible scientific literature' and 'informed choice,' but experts and public health professionals dispute that these efforts are grounded in science.
Some anti-science advocates have built lucrative careers or businesses (e.g., selling raw milk) tied to the anti-vaccine movement, suggesting financial incentives drive policy influence.
Rising anti-science sentiment is linked to declining vaccination rates, leading to outbreaks of preventable diseases like measles and whooping cough.
A personal case — the death of Liam Dahlberg, an 8-year-old with asthma and allergies, from Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) — illustrates the human cost of falling vaccination rates.
One in five kindergartners in certain U.S. counties do not meet vaccination requirements, signaling a growing public health risk.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a central figure in the anti-science movement, having led the 'Make America Healthy Again' (MAHA) agenda, which has influenced the introduction and adoption of anti-vaccine and anti-fluoride bills across U.S. state legislatures.

namedEntities.name: Make America Healthy Again (MAHA)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: MAHA is a key driver behind the wave of anti-science legislation, promoting policies that oppose vaccines and fluoride, and organizing nationwide campaigns to influence state lawmakers.

namedEntities.name: Stand for Health Freedom
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group supports anti-vaccine and raw milk policies, and is one of the four national organizations linked to Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that actively promotes anti-science legislation in statehouses.

namedEntities.name: National Vaccine Information Center (NVIC)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: NVIC opposes science-based public health policies, including vaccine mandates, and supports anti-vaccine legislation. Its leader claims the pandemic response was overly restrictive, fueling anti-science sentiment.

namedEntities.name: Weston A. Price Foundation
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The foundation promotes raw milk consumption and opposes fluoride, and is one of the groups supporting anti-science bills that target public health protections.

namedEntities.name: Raw milk

summaryOfNewsArticle: A wave of anti-science legislation has been introduced in 50 U.S. states in 2025, with over 350 anti-vaccine bills and more than 70 targeting fluoride or raw milk safety. These bills are largely supported by national groups linked to Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s 'Make America Healthy Again' movement, which promotes policies that undermine science-based public health protections. The movement employs sophisticated political tactics, including coordinated campaigns and lobbying, and some advocates profit from selling raw milk or promoting anti-vaccine beliefs. Despite claims of scientific legitimacy, experts and public health officials argue these efforts are anti-science. Declining vaccination rates have led to outbreaks of diseases like measles and whooping cough, and personal tragedies — such as the death of an 8-year-old boy from Hib — highlight the real human cost of these policies.
title: Wave of Anti-Science Bills Sweeps U.S. Statehouses in 2025, Linked to Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
